sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a combustion reaction
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the combustion of methane gas (CH4) given the balanced chemical equation:

CH4(g) + 2O2(g) -> CO2(g) + 2H2O(l)

The relevant standard enthalpies of formation are:
ΔHf°[CH4(g)] = -74.87 kJ/mol
ΔHf°[CO2(g)] = -393.5 kJ/mol
ΔHf°[H2O(l)] = -285.8 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the combustion of methane gas (CH4), we can use the following formula:

ΔH° = Σ ΔHf°(products) - Σ ΔHf°(reactants)

For the given balanced chemical equation:

CH4(g) + 2O2(g) -> CO2(g) + 2H2O(l)

The standard enthalpies of formation for the reactants are:
ΔHf°[CH4(g)] = -74.87 kJ/mol
ΔHf°[O2(g)] = 0 kJ/mol (since O2 is in its standard state)

The standard enthalpies of formation for the products are:
ΔHf°[CO2(g)] = -393.5 kJ/mol
ΔHf°[H2O(l)] = -285.8 kJ/mol

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

ΔH° = [(-393.5 kJ/mol) + 2(-285.8 kJ/mol)] - [(-74.87 kJ/mol) + 0]

ΔH° = (-393.5 - 571.6 + 74.87) kJ/mol

ΔH° = -890.23 kJ/mol

Therefore, the standard enthalpy change for the combustion of methane gas (CH4) is -890.23 kJ/mol.
